across.text: They dread running dry
across.explanation: DEHYDRATE(i.e. to “dry”. Rather apt at the moment). “Running” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of THEY DREAD. Nicely worked, credit where it’s due.

across.text: Type of spring
across.explanation: FOUNT. Solution satisfies a “type[face]” – Chambers would suggest font is a variant spelling of fount and not the other way around. Interesting… – and a “spring” of water.

across.text: Plant is high around noon
across.explanation: INSTALL(i.e. to set in place or “plant”). Solution is IS and TALL (i.e. “high”) all wrapped “around” N (a recognised abbreviation of “noon”), like so: I(N)S-TALL.

across.text: What determines fate of king beginning to ask about power
across.explanation: KARMA(i.e. “what determines fate”). Solution is K (a recognised abbreviation of “king” used in chess) and A (i.e. “beginning to ask”, i.e. the first letter of “ask”) all wrapped “about” ARM (i.e. “power”, figuratively speaking), like so: K-(ARM)-A.

across.text: Military commander one’s surprised in castle courtyard
across.explanation: WARLORD(i.e. “military commander”). Solution is LOR’ (i.e. “one’s surprised”, i.e. an exclamatory word, in this case a contraction of LORD) placed “in” WARD (i.e. “castle courtyard”, though technically this can be any guarded place), like so: WAR(LOR’)D.

across.text: What might indicate it to be a poor area
across.explanation: INNER CITY(i.e. “poor area”). Solution also cryptically satisfies “what might indicate it”, i.e. how “it” forms the INNER part of the word CITY.

across.text: Consultants have money cut as outside roster
across.explanation: SPECIALISTS(i.e. “consultants”). Solution is SPECIE (i.e. coined “money”, from the Latin) with the last letter removed (indicated by “cut”) and the remainder followed by AS once it has been placed “outside” of LIST (i.e. “roster”), like so: SPECI-A(LIST)S.

across.text: I target urge desperately to bring matter up again
across.explanation: REGURGITATE(i.e. “bring matter up again”). “Desperately” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of I TARGET URGE.

across.text: Doctor takes side of blade to explore deeper?
across.explanation: DREDGE(i.e. “to explore deeper”). Solution is DR (a recognised abbreviation of “doctor”) followed by EDGE (i.e. “side of blade”).

across.text: Pill taken before operation here in theatre?
across.explanation: TABLETOP(i.e. “here in theatre” – basically the top of an operating table. Much too vague for me. There was genuinely a feeling of “ugh, is that really the answer?!” when I twigged it). Solution is TABLET (i.e. “pill”) followed by OP (short for operation).

across.text: Medical officer leads because of the possibility of assault
across.explanation: MOLEST(i.e. “assault”). Solution is MO (a recognised abbreviation of “medical officer”) followed by or “leading” LEST (i.e. “because of the possibility of” – is it really though? Chambers would suggest: “so that not” or “for fear that”. Even if I squint my eyes really hard, I’m not seeing much overlap there).

across.text: Catching girl leaving – not good – earlier
across.explanation: LASSOING(i.e. “catching”). Solution is LASS GOING (i.e. “girl leaving”) with the first G removed (indicated by “not good – earlier” – G being a recognised abbreviation of “good”), like so: LASS-OING.

across.text: Run round southeast in rugged old hunting land, a foolish pursuit
across.explanation: WILD-GOOSE CHASE(i.e. “foolish pursuit”). Solution is GO (i.e. “run”), O (i.e. “round”) and SE (a recognised abbreviation of “southeast”) all placed “in” between WILD (i.e. “rugged”) and CHASE (i.e. “hunting land”). I can see no archaic markers against any of the definitions of CHASE, so why the redundant use of “old” in this clue, setter? At best it’s untidy, and at worst it’s an attempt to unfairly throw solvers off the scent using a word often abbreviated as O. Ugh.

across.text: Doubt in the capacity of learner driver before motorway
across.explanation: QUALM(i.e. “doubt”). Solution is QUA (i.e. “in the capacity of” in Latin) followed by L (i.e. “learner driver”) and M (a recognised abbreviation of “motorway”).

across.text: Mostly wrong backing railway system run by clockwork
across.explanation: ORRERY(i.e. “system run by clockwork”, being a mechanical representation of the solar system). Solution is ERROR (i.e. “wrong”) with it’s last letter removed (indicated by “mostly”) and the remainder reversed (indicated by “backing”). This is then followed by RY (a recognised abbreviation of “railway”), like so: ORRE-RY.

across.text: Restricted activity near key society dance
across.explanation: CLOSED SHOP(i.e. “restricted activity”). Solution is CLOSE (i.e. “near”) followed by D (i.e. “[musical] key”), then S (a recognised abbreviation of “society”) and HOP (i.e. “dance”).

across.text: What can be done to uranium giving gold?
across.explanation: ENRICHMENT. Solution satisfies “what can be done to uranium” and, playfully, “giving gold”.

across.text: A long way into a meal
across.explanation: FARINA(i.e. “meal” or ground corn. No, me neither). Solution is FAR (i.e. “a long way”) followed by IN (i.e. “into” – ugh, please…) and A.

across.text: What helps reach peak mine working
across.explanation: PITON(i.e. “what helps reach peak”, an iron peg used in mountaineering). Solution is PIT (i.e. “mine”) followed by ON (i.e. “working”). One nailed from the wordplay.

across.text: Noted author lacked richness somehow
across.explanation: CHARLES DICKENS(i.e. “noted author”). “Somehow” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of LACKED RICHNESS.

across.text: Photographic image for example held by son
across.explanation: NEGATIVE(i.e. “photographic image”). Solution is EG (i.e. “for example”, after the Latinexempli gratia) placed in or “held by” NATIVE (i.e. “son” or countryman), like so: N(EG)ATIVE.

across.text: Explanation of treachery when abducting leader
across.explanation: REASON(i.e. “explanation”). Solution is TREASON (i.e. “treachery”) with the first letter removed (indicated by “when abducting leader”).

across.text: Determined what puzzles like this often are not?
across.explanation: RESOLVED(i.e. “determined”). When written as RE-SOLVED the solution playfully satisfies “what puzzles like this often are not”. “Often” is probably a nod to the best-of Jumbo cryptic books that get published every September on a four-ish year lag from their original publication. I usually buy these books, but pretty soon I’ll start seeing Jumbos I’ve solved already here.

across.text: Take away empty drainage pipe
across.explanation: DEDUCT(i.e. “take away”). Solution is DE (i.e. “empty drainage”, i.e. the word “drainage” with all its middle letters removed) followed by DUCT (i.e. “pipe”).

across.text: Money perhaps for crude trollop – dear, unfortunately
across.explanation: PETRODOLLAR(i.e. “money perhaps for crude” oil). “Unfortunately” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TROLLOP DEAR.

across.text: Bombing raid round British ocean damaged navigation aid
across.explanation: RADIO BEACON(i.e. “navigation aid”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “bombing”) of RAID followed by O (i.e. “round”), then B (a recognised abbreviation of “British”) and another anagram (indicated by “damaged”), this time of OCEAN, like so: RADI-O-B-EACON.

across.text: Routine opera illuminated by unknown
across.explanation: NORMALITY(i.e. “routine”). Solution is NORMA (i.e. an “opera” by Vincenzo Bellini – its signature tune,Casta Diva, is used in those Jean-Paul Gaultier adverts you see on telly) followed by LIT (i.e. “illuminated”) and Y (i.e. “unknown” – setters love referring to X, Y or Z in solutions as unknowns).

across.text: Move casually, catching Liberal conspirator
across.explanation: PLOTTER(i.e. “conspirator”). Solution is POTTER (i.e. “move casually”) wrapped around or “catching” L (a recognised abbreviation of “Liberal”), like so: P(L)OTTER.

across.text: Earlier head of house
across.explanation: PRIOR. Solution satisfies “earlier” and a religious “head of house”.

across.text: Plant is in my control
across.explanation: MASTERY(i.e. “control”). Solution is ASTER (i.e. “plant”) placed “in” MY, like so: M(ASTER)Y.

across.text: Hangs around birds with a becoming uniform
across.explanation: LURKS(i.e. “hangs around”). Solution is LARKS (i.e. “birds”) “with a becoming uniform”, i.e. swapping A for U (“uniform” in the phonetic alphabet) like so: L(A)RKS => L(U)RKS.

across.text: Fool, upper-class, new in career shows certainty
across.explanation: ASSURANCE(i.e. “certainty”). Solution is ASS (i.e. “fool”) followed by U (a recognised abbreviation of the “upper-class” rarely seen outside of cryptic crosswords) and N (a recognised abbreviation of “new”) once placed “in” RACE (i.e. to “career”), like so: ASS-U-RA(N)CE.

down.text: What could be fast protecting king? Earthworks
down.explanation: DYKES(i.e. “earthworks”). Solution is DYES (i.e. “what could be fast”) wrapped around or “protecting” K (a recognised abbreviation of “king” used in chess”), like so: DY(K)ES.

down.text: Researcher’s goal is revolutionary mode of transport
down.explanation: HORSELESS CARRIAGE(i.e. “mode of transport”). “Revolutionary” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of RESEARCHER’S GOAL IS.

down.text: Where to go after dinner to entice home stable boy
down.explanation: DRAWING ROOM(i.e. “where to go after dinner”, if you’ve got a house that big). Solution is DRAW (i.e. “entice”) followed by IN (i.e. at “home”) and GROOM (i.e. “stable boy”).

down.text: Answer excellent for American also
down.explanation: AS WELL(i.e. “also”). Solution is A (a recognised abbreviation of “answer”, as in Q&A) followed by SWELL (i.e. “excellent for American”).

down.text: European hope, mostly about new language
down.explanation: ETRUSCAN(i.e. “language” of an ancient state in Italy. So not on Google Translate, then). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “European”) followed by TRUST (i.e. “hope”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “mostly”), then CA (i.e. “about”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “circa”), then N (a recognised abbreviation of “new”), like so: E-TRUS-CA-N.

down.text: Rambling stories of old men
down.explanation: FOOT SOLDIERS(i.e. “men”). “Rambling” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of STORIES OF OLD.

down.text: One taking over part of down train
down.explanation: UNDERSTUDY(i.e. “one taking over [acting] part”). Solution is UNDER (i.e. “down”) followed by STUDY (i.e. to “train”).

down.text: Fine golf gadget
down.explanation: THING(i.e. “gadget” – Chambers supports it, stating a gadget can be “a what-d’you-call-it”). Solution is THIN (i.e. “fine”) followed by G (“golf” in the phonetic alphabet).

down.text: Fool to overlook what diversion does if never taken all the way
down.explanation: IGNORAMUS(i.e. “fool”). Solution is IGNORE (i.e. “overlook”) and AMUSE (i.e. “what diversion does”) once the last letter has been removed from each (indicated by “if never taken all the way”), like so: IGNOR-AMUS.

down.text: Channel 50 delivered good service with no licence?
down.explanation: STRAIT-LACED(i.e. “with no licence” or being “narrow in principles”(Chambers)). Solution is STRAIT (i.e. “channel”) followed by L (i.e. “50” as a Roman numeral), then ACED (i.e. “delivered good service” in tennis).

down.text: Saintism regularly has a feminine side
down.explanation: ANIMA(i.e. “feminine side” in Jungian psychology – a word I knew, weirdly). Solution is ANIM (i.e. “saintism regularly”, i.e. every other letter of SAINTISM) followed by A.

down.text: Non-professionals can be idle people, not unknown
down.explanation: LAYMEN(i.e. “non-professionals”). Solution is LAZY MEN (i.e. “idle people”) with the Z removed (indicated by “not unknown”, already discussed).

down.text: Have many branches of food shops around Quebec with this from France
down.explanation: DELIQUESCE(i.e. “have many branches” – a botanical term describing the veins in a leaf, it seems. Which would be lovely if we were being asked to derive an adjectival solution. Instead, the solution is a verb. In other words, “have many branches” ought to have led to the solution DELIQUESCENT, not to DELIQUESCE. Grammar police inbound, setter. Assume the position). Solution is DELIS (i.e. “food shops”, short for delicatessens) wrapped “around” QUE (shortened form of “Quebec”, Q in the phonetic alphabet) followed by CE (i.e. “this from France”, i.e. the French for “this”).

down.text: Declare in favour of state
down.explanation: PROCLAIM(i.e. “declare”). Solution is PRO (i.e. “in favour of”) followed by CLAIM (i.e. to “state”).

down.text: Complex ways of combining pasta, initially just with oil
down.explanation: SPAGHETTI JUNCTION(i.e. “complex ways”, ways in this case being another word for roads). Solution is SPAGHETTI (i.e. “pasta”) followed by J (i.e. “initially just”, i.e. the first letter of “just”) and UNCTION (i.e. “oil”).

down.text: Teach – and where to do it
down.explanation: INFORM(i.e. “teach”). When written as IN FORM the solution also satisfies “where to do it [i.e. teach]”, forms being another word for school classes.

down.text: Object to including mere divorce case defendant
down.explanation: RESPONDENT(i.e. “divorce case defendant”). Solution is RESENT (i.e. “object to”) wrapped around or “including” POND (i.e. “mere”, or body of water), like so: RES(POND)ENT.

down.text: Marches right on in fine row
down.explanation: FRONTIER(i.e. “marches” – a variant meaning of the word is a boundary or border). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of “right”) and ON both placed “in” between F (a recognised abbreviation of “fine” used in grading pencils) and TIER (i.e. “row”), like so: F-(R-ON)-TIER.

down.text: Young boy’s quiet state
down.explanation: SHAVER(i.e. informal word for a “young boy”). Solution is SH (i.e. “quiet”) followed by AVER (i.e. to “state”).

down.text: Shameful supporting vice admiral’s bragging
down.explanation: VAINGLORIOUS(i.e. “bragging”). Solution is INGLORIOUS (i.e. “shameful”) placed after or “supporting” – this being a down clue – VA (a recognised abbreviation of “vice admiral”), like so: VA-INGLORIOUS.

down.text: Store into which oldest cargo could be moved?
down.explanation: COLD STORAGE(i.e. “store” – ugh again, setter. Surely a better alternative was available. I mean, you’ve got a derivative form of the target word sitting right there in the solution. I’m beginning to doubt the editor clapped eyes on this puzzle before publication). “Could be moved” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of OLDEST CARGO.

down.text: Bit player in speech, one acting with good force?
down.explanation: PEACEKEEPER(i.e. “one acting with good force”, presumably the United Nations). “In speech” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of PIECE (i.e. “bit”) followed by KEEPER (i.e. “player” in a number of ball games, e.g. football).

down.text: Building ark fashioned with cypress
down.explanation: SKYSCRAPER(i.e. “building”). “Fashioned” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of ARK and CYPRESS.

down.text: Chosen junior in later stages will get it years later?
down.explanation: SENIORITY. The solution satisfies the clue in general, but also comprises SEN and IOR (i.e. “chosen junior in later stages”, i.e. the last halves of “chosen” and “junior”), followed by IT and Y (a recognised abbreviation of “years”).

down.text: Feud with old soldier about issue with volunteers
down.explanation: VENDETTA(i.e. “feud”). Solution is VET (i.e. “old soldier”, short for veteran) wrapped “about” END (i.e. “issue”) and followed by TA (i.e. “volunteers”, i.e. the Territorial Army of old), like so: V(END)ET-TA.

down.text: English horse, male, Black Beauty perhaps?
down.explanation: EPONYM(i.e. “Black Beauty perhaps” – an eponymous work is one that shares its name with its central character or its creator (as in album titles)). Solution is E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) followed by PONY (i.e. “horse”) and M (a recognised abbreviation of “male”).

down.text: Sees benches in quadrangles
down.explanation: COURTS. A triple-header, I believe, where the solution satisfies “sees” or pays attention to, “benches” or assemblies of judges, and “quadrangles” or four-sided areas.

down.text: Names, regular features of the Proms, succeeded
down.explanation: TERMS(i.e. “names”). Solution is TERM (i.e. “regular features of the Proms”, i.e. every other letter ofTHEPROMS) followed by S (a recognised abbreviation of “succeeded”).

down.text: Forged alloy providing firm support
down.explanation: LOYAL(i.e. “firm support”). “Forged” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of ALLOY.

down.text: Steel used to form some inner vessel
down.explanation: NERVE(i.e. “steel”). “Some” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: IN(NER VE)SSEL.
